ctas

00001 #!/bin/bash
00002 # bashscript - Copyright (C) 2008 Anton Maksimenko <antonmx@gmail.com>
00003 
00004 
00005 # /// \file   ctas
00006 # /// \brief Main executable
00007 # /// \details Small shell script which invokes one of the executables
00008 # /// belonging to the package. All executables should (but not must)
00009 # /// be invoked via the interface provided by this script. Actually it
00010 # /// should be the obly executable installed into the bin directory.
00011 # /// This file is created by the ./configure scrupt from input file
00012 # /// 'ctas.in' and therefore doxygen command should be run after the
00013 # /// configuration.
00014 # /// Unfortunately the doxygen does not support bash shell script
00015 # /// language. Therefore this file is not documented as it should be.
00016 
00017 
00018 
00019 # /// \cond
00020 
00021 prefix="/home/antonmx/work/projects/ctascmake/image"
00022 exec_prefix="/home/antonmx/work/projects/ctascmake/image/libexec/ctas"
00023 lib_prefix="/home/antonmx/work/projects/ctascmake/image/lib/ctas"
00024 PACKAGE="ctas"
00025 
00026 
00027 description="Interface to all tools in the '${PACKAGE}' package."
00028 command=$(basename $0)
00029 
00030 listcom() {
00031     for execom in $(ls ${exec_prefix}) ; do
00032         echo $(basename $execom);
00033     done
00034 }
00035 
00036 longestname=0
00037 for com in $(listcom) ; do
00038     if [ "${#com}" -gt "$longestname" ] ; then
00039         longestname=${#com}
00040     fi
00041 done
00042 let "longestname += 2"
00043 
00044 checkcom() {
00045     ls -a ${exec_prefix} | grep -q "^$1\$"
00046 }
00047 
00048 execom() {
00049     LD_LIBRARY_PATH="${lib_prefix}:${LD_LIBRARY_PATH}" \
00050     LIBRARY_PATH="${lib_prefix}:${LIBRARY_PATH}" \
00051     exec ${exec_prefix}/$@
00052 }
00053 
00054 showusage() {
00055     echo "$description"
00056     echo "Use '-h | --help' option for more information."
00057 }
00058 
00059 # I assume that each command in the package, if invoked with no arguments,
00060 # briefly describes itself in the first string of the output.
00061 describeself() {
00062     if checkcom $1 ; then
00063         execom $1 | head -n 1
00064     fi
00065 }
00066 
00067 showhelp() {
00068     echo "$description"
00069     echo "Usage: $command <tool> [TOOL SPECIFIC ... ]"
00070     echo "TOOLS:"
00071     for com in $(listcom) ; do
00072         printf "    %-${longestname}s%s\n" "$com" "$(describeself ${com})"
00073     done
00074     printf "    %-${longestname}s%s\n" "list"  "Lists all tools."
00075     printf "    %-${longestname}s%s\n" "help"  "Prints this help message."
00076     printf "    %-${longestname}s%s\n" "usage" "Outputs brief usage message."
00077     echo "TOOL SPECIFIC:"
00078     echo "    Use command's help or usage for specific information:"
00079     echo "    $command <command> -h | --help | -? | --usage"
00080 }
00081 
00082 
00083 
00084 if [ "$#" -eq "0" ] ; then
00085     showusage >&2
00086     exit 1;
00087 else
00088     comm=$1
00089 fi
00090 
00091 case "$comm" in
00092     "-h"|"h"|"help"|"--help")  showhelp ; exit 0 ;;
00093     "-?"|"u"|"usage"|"--usage") showusage ; exit 0 ;;
00094     "-l"|"l"|"list"|"--list")  listcom ; exit 0 ;;
00095     *) shift ;;
00096 esac
00097 
00098 if checkcom $comm  ; then
00099     execom $comm $@
00100 else
00101     echo "The packege does not provide command '$comm'."
00102     exit 1;
00103 fi
00104 
00105 # /// \endcond
